results.headline: Eyeing Pornography That Uses the Holocaust as Titillation
results.summary_short: Ari Libsker’s “Stalags” examines the craze for pornographic pulp novels about Nazi abuse.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stalags

results.headline: Behold a Dark Horse, Bowing to Everyone
results.summary_short: This fascinating Japanese documentary is likely to challenge some very basic American assumptions about democracy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Campaign

results.headline: Watch Out for That Malevolent Jungle Vine
results.summary_short: More disgusting than scary, “The Ruins” is the latest in a long line of horror films about upper-middle-class travelers being terrorized in unfamiliar environments.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ruins

results.headline: The Deals Made to Go on in a So-Called Simple Life
results.summary_short: “Tuya’s Marriage” finds an austere beauty in a landscape of scrub and grassland ringed by forbidding slate-blue mountains.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tuya's Marriage

results.headline: An Unlikely Friendship
results.summary_short: A spoonful of fashion helps the feminism go down in “Nana,” a delightful pop fairy tale that speaks to young women in the language of sisterhood and self-direction.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nana

results.headline: Navigating a Zigzag Course in a Sea of Relationships
results.summary_short: “Jellyfish” is the kind of movie in which the accidental connections between lonely city dwellers are given a magical glow of serendipity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jellyfish

results.headline: Another Balloon Over Paris, With Lives Adrift Below
results.summary_short: The luscious red orb in “Flight of the Red Balloon” is as much a reminder of the precariousness of life as an emblem of innocence.
results.display_title: The Flight of the Red Balloon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Flight of the Red Balloon

results.headline: Only Rock ’N’ Roll, but They’re Still at It
results.summary_short: As the director of the documentary “Shine a Light,” Martin Scorsese is a besotted rock ’n’ roll fan who wholeheartedly embraces its mythology.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shine a Light

results.headline: On the List
results.summary_short: The screenwriter Daniel Waters has some funny films to his name, but “Sex and Death 101” is not one of them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex and Death 101

results.headline: Crossing Into the Deep End, Where Desire Is Fathomed
results.summary_short: The flowers that bloom in the French film “Water Lilies” belong to a familiar cinematic species, the newly sexualized teenage girl.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Water Lilies

results.headline: On the Road, With Melancholia and a Hankering for Pie and Ice Cream
results.summary_short: In “My Blueberry Nights,” Wong Kar-wai and his cinematographer, Darius Khondji, make America look so pretty that you may have trouble recognizing it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Blueberry Nights

results.headline: Listen Up, Boys: Break Fizzy and Fake Insouciance
results.summary_short: “Leatherheads” labors so strenuously to approximate some of the old screwball spirit of the ’30s and ’40s that it winds up in traction.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Leatherheads

results.headline: Missed Adventures
results.summary_short: If “Nim’s Island” were anything but a children’s movie, the casting genius who suggested Jodie Foster as a potential love interest for Gerard Butler would be looking for a new occupation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nim's Island

results.headline: The Judge, the Director and the Vagaries of Justice
results.summary_short: “Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired” is a subtly intelligent and sharply argued documentary.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired

results.headline: Up, Up and a Ways Off the Track
results.summary_short: To call “Superhero Movie” a satire, or even a parody, of the genre specified in its title would be misleading, since those terms imply at least an attempt at wit.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Superhero Movie

results.headline: Out on the Waves
results.summary_short: A confused young artist is torn between his family and his future in “Shelter,” a sensitive romantic drama from the writer and director Jonah Markowitz.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shelter

results.headline: Cherchez le Sugar Daddy (et Sugar Mom)
results.summary_short: Forget reality shows exalting American gluttony and savor the more refined amenities on the coasts of southern France in the cynical Gallic comedy “Priceless.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Priceless

results.headline: An Aristocratic Look and a Powerhouse Personality
results.summary_short: “Hats Off” is a documentary tribute to the 93-year-old actress Mimi Weddell, one of those people for whom the word “individual” seems especially apt.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hats Off

results.headline: Good-Natured Raunchiness
results.summary_short: “A Four Letter Word” is a surprisingly endearing romantic comedy that explores gay relationships with low-budget verve.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Four Letter Word

results.headline: Cut by a Diamond-Crusted Glass Ceiling
results.summary_short: “Flawless” is a mildly diverting period heist movie in which an odd couple conspire to loot an evil London diamond company, for which they both work.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flawless
